<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_io_block_write:
```c
int metal_io_block_write(struct metal_io_region *io, unsigned long offset,
	       const void *restrict src, int len)
{
	unsigned char *ptr = metal_io_virt(io, offset);
	const unsigned char *source = src;
	int retlen;

	if (!ptr)
		return -ERANGE;
	if ((offset + len) > io->size)
		len = io->size - offset;
	retlen = len;
	if (io->ops.block_write) {
		retlen = (*io->ops.block_write)(
			io, offset, src, memory_order_seq_cst, len);
	} else {
		while ( len && (
			((uintptr_t)ptr % sizeof(int)) ||
			((uintptr_t)source % sizeof(int)))) {
			*(unsigned char *)ptr =
				*(const unsigned char *)source;
			ptr++;
			source++;
			len--;
		}
		for (; len >= (int)sizeof(int); ptr += sizeof(int),
					source += sizeof(int),
					len -= sizeof(int))
			*(unsigned int *)ptr = *(const unsigned int *)source;
		for (; len != 0; ptr++, source++, len--)
			*(unsigned char *)ptr =
				*(const unsigned char *)source;
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_seq_cst);
	}
	return retlen;
}
```
</target_code>

suspicious_frags:
retlen = (*io->ops.block_write)(
			io, offset, src, memory_order_seq_cst, len);
explanation: The selected fragments are those that perform pointer arithmetic, adjust or use len, or copy memory byte/word-wise — these are the locations where out-of-bounds accesses could occur (including due to signed/unsigned arithmetic, negative len, truncation when assigning size_t to int, or incorrect assumptions about source buffer length/alignment). Other parts of the function do not perform memory copies or pointer arithmetic that could create out-of-bounds accesses and therefore need not be investigated for Rule 21.17: - The initial null check (if (!ptr) return -ERANGE;) prevents dereferencing a NULL region pointer. - The atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_seq_cst); call does not perform pointer dereferencing or buffer accesses. - The final return (return retlen;) and the local variable declarations alone do not cause accesses beyond object bounds. - Definitions of struct metal_io_region and struct metal_io_ops are type/layout declarations and do not themselves perform memory accesses. These were therefore not included as suspicious fragments.
